bcl:section.bcl:text:
This Act is to be administered and interpreted in accordance with the following
          principles:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the court should not be asked to appoint, and should not appoint, guardians
            unless alternatives, such as the provision of support and assistance, have been tried or
            carefully considered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Until the contrary is demonstrated, every adult is presumed to be capable of
            making decisions about the adult's personal care, health care and financial
            affairs.

An adult's way of communicating with others is not grounds for deciding that he
            or she is incapable of making decisions about anything referred to in subsection
              (1).
If a person has reason to believe that an adult may be incapable of managing the adult's financial affairs, the person may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is a health care provider, request a qualified health care provider to assess the adult's incapability, or
in any case, notify the Public Guardian and Trustee of the person's belief, and the Public Guardian and Trustee may request a qualified health care provider to assess the adult's incapability.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after assessing the adult according to prescribed procedures, the qualified health care provider determines that the adult is incapable of managing that adult's financial affairs, the qualified health care provider may, using the prescribed form, report the adult's incapability to a health authority designate.

If a health authority designate receives a report under subsection (2) of an adult's incapability, the health authority designate may issue a certificate of incapability in respect of the adult, if satisfied that, based on the report and any additional information the designate receives,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult needs to make decisions about the adult's financial affairs,
the adult is incapable of making those decisions,
the adult needs, and will benefit from, the assistance and protection of a statutory property guardian,
the needs of the adult would not be sufficiently met by alternative means of assistance, and
either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the adult has not granted power over all of the adult's financial affairs to an attorney under an enduring power of attorney, or

bcl:text.#text: an attorney has been granted power as described in subparagraph (i) but is not complying with the attorney's duties under the  or the enduring power of attorney, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health authority designate must not issue a certificate of incapability unless the health authority designate has first

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consulted with the Public Guardian and Trustee,

notified the adult, and, if contact information is known to the health authority designate, the adult's spouse or a near relative of the adult, of the intention to issue the certificate and the reasons for issuing it, and
given each person who received notice under paragraph (b) a reasonable opportunity to respond.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (3.1) (b), notification need not be given to the adult, to another person referred to in that subsection, or to either the adult or another person referred to in that subsection, if the health authority designate has reason to believe that notification may result in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serious physical or mental harm to the adult, or
significant damage or loss to the adult's property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the health authority designate issues a certificate of incapability, the health authority designate must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: forward the certificate to the Public Guardian and Trustee;

advise the adult, and, if contact information is known to the health authority designate, the adult's spouse or a near relative of the adult, that a certificate of incapability in respect of the adult has been issued, and provide each of them with a copy of the certificate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Public Guardian and Trustee is the adult's statutory property guardian as of the date on which the certificate of incapability was signed by the health authority designate who issued it.
[Repealed 2014-9-1.]

bcl:text.#text: This section does not apply if the adult has a committee, appointed under the , responsible for managing the adult's affairs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When Public Guardian and Trustee becomes statutory property guardian

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On becoming an adult's statutory property guardian, the Public Guardian and Trustee

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must advise the adult, and, if contact information is known to the Public Guardian and Trustee, the adult's spouse or a near relative of the adult, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Public Guardian and Trustee is the adult's statutory property guardian and may make decisions respecting the adult's financial affairs, and
the adult has the rights described in subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On being advised that the Public Guardian and Trustee is an adult's statutory property guardian,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult, or a person acting on behalf of the adult, may request, within the prescribed time, a second assessment of the adult's incapability conducted by a qualified health care provider in accordance with prescribed assessment procedures, and

if, following the second assessment, a qualified health care provider determines that the adult is incapable of managing that adult's financial affairs, the adult, or a person acting on behalf of the adult, may apply to the court under section 35 for a review of the determination.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The incapability of an adult who has a statutory property guardian must be reassessed by a qualified health care provider, in accordance with prescribed assessment procedures, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult's statutory property guardian informs the body that designated the health authority designate who issued the certificate of incapability that a reassessment should occur,
the adult requests a reassessment and has not been reassessed within the preceding 12 months, or
the court orders that a reassessment occur under section 35 (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court review of finding of incapability

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an adult has been determined to be incapable of managing the adult's financial affairs under section 33 (3) or 34, the adult may apply to the court for a review of that determination.
The following are parties to a review under this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult who has been determined to be incapable;
the body that designated the health authority designate who issued the certificate of incapability;

bcl:text.#text: if ordered by the court, a person appointed, under the , as committee for the adult following a declaration under that Act that the adult is incapable of managing himself or herself.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court may order the adult to attend at the time and place the court directs and submit to an assessment of incapability conducted by a qualified health care provider in accordance with prescribed assessment procedures.
The court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm the determination of incapability, or
reject the determination of incapability and order that the statutory property guardianship is ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Statutory property guardianship ends if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Public Guardian and Trustee is the statutory property guardian and the Public Guardian and Trustee

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is satisfied that the adult no longer needs a statutory property guardian, and
has provided notice to the adult that the adult no longer has a statutory property guardian,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: following a second assessment under section 33 (3), or a reassessment under section 34,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a qualified health care provider determines that the adult is capable of managing the adult's financial affairs and notifies a health authority designate of the determination, and
the health authority designate accepts the determination of capability and notifies the Public Guardian and Trustee of the determination,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court ends the statutory property guardianship under section 35, or

bcl:text.#text: the court appoints, under the , a committee responsible for managing the adult's affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If statutory property guardianship ends under subsection (3), the certificate of incapability issued under section 32 is cancelled.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Support and Assistance for Abused and Neglected Adults

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The purpose of this Part is to provide for support and assistance for adults who
          are abused or neglected and who are unable to seek support and assistance because
          of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: physical restraint,
a physical handicap that limits their ability to seek help, or

an illness, disease, injury or other condition that affects their ability to
            make decisions about the abuse or neglect.

bcl:text.#text: In this Part,  includes a committee under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
This Part applies whether an adult is abused or neglected in a public place, in
            the adult's home, a relative's home, a care facility or any other place except a
            correctional centre.
This Part does not

                  (Consent) and Care Facility (Admission) Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prevent an adult's representative or guardian from refusing health care for
              the adult in accordance with wishes the adult expressed while capable, even if the
              refusal will result in the adult's death.

may report the circumstances to a designated agency.

Despite the  and the , a person must not disclose or be compelled to

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
No action for damages may be brought against a person for making a report under

a refusal to issue or renew a licence or certificate to practise a profession

a denial or cancellation of permission to practise in a hospital or a refusal
              to renew that permission.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Determining if the adult needs support and assistance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A designated agency must determine whether an adult needs support and assistance
            if the agency

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receives a report under section 46,
has reason to believe that an adult is abused or neglected, or

receives a report that the adult's representative, guardian or monitor has
              been hindered from visiting or speaking with the adult.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the designated agency determines that the adult does not need support and
            assistance, the designated agency

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must take no further action, and
may advise the Public Guardian and Trustee.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the designated agency determines that the adult needs support and assistance,
            the designated agency may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
refer the adult to available health care, social, legal, accommodation or
              other services;
assist the adult in obtaining those services;
inform the Public Guardian and Trustee;

investigate to determine if the adult is abused or neglected and is unable,
              for any of the reasons mentioned in section 44, to seek support and
              assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In conducting an investigation described in section 47 (3) (d), a designated
            agency must make every reasonable effort to interview the adult.
In addition, the designated agency may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
interview the adult's spouse, the adult's near relatives, the adult's friends
              or anyone else who may assist in the investigation, and

obtain any information that the circumstances require, including a report
              from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a health care provider who has examined the adult,

any agency that provides or has provided health or social services to the
                adult, and
any person that manages the adult's financial affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Section
              62 applies to information referred to in subsection (2) (b).

A designated agency that is conducting an investigation described in section 47 (3)
            (d) may apply to the court for an order under subsection (2) if someone
            from the designated agency

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
believes it is necessary to enter any premises in order to interview the
              adult, and
is denied entry to the premises by anyone, including the adult.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On application under subsection (1), the court may make an order
            authorizing either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
someone from the designated agency to enter the premises and interview the
              adult;

bcl:link.in:doc:
Health Care
                  (Consent) and Care Facility (Admission) Act

bcl:text.#text:
a health care provider, as defined in the , to enter the
              premises to examine the adult to determine whether health care should be
              provided.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an application for a court order will result in a delay that could result in
            harm to the adult, a justice of the peace may issue a warrant authorizing someone from
            the designated agency to enter the premises and interview the adult.

The court may only make an order under subsection (2), and a justice of
            the peace may only issue a warrant under subsection (3), if there is
            reason to believe that the adult

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is abused or neglected, and

is, for any of the reasons mentioned in section 44, unable to seek
              support and assistance.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If a designated agency has reason to believe that a criminal offence has been
          committed against an adult about whom a report is made under section 46, the designated
          agency must report the facts to the police.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
After conducting an investigation described in section 47 (3) (d), the
            designated agency may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: take no further action;

refer the adult to available health care, social, legal, accommodation or
              other services;

report the case to the Public Guardian and Trustee or another
              agency;

bcl:text: apply to the court for an interim order requiring a person
for a period of up to 90 days;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
to stop residing at and stay away from the premises where the adult lives,
                unless the person is the owner or lessee of the premises,

not to visit, communicate with, harass or interfere with the
                adult,

not to have any contact or association with the adult or the adult's
                financial affairs, or
to comply with any other restriction of relations with the adult,

bcl:text.#text: apply to the court for an order under Part 7 of the  for the support of the adult;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prepare a support and assistance plan that specifies any services needed by
              the adult, including health care, accommodation, social, legal or financial
              services.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An order may be made under subsection (1) (e) without notice to the adult or a
            person against whom the order is sought, if there are reasonable grounds for believing
            that proceeding without notice is necessary for the immediate protection of the
            adult.

On application under subsection (1) (e), the court may make an interim
            order described in that subsection if the designated agency establishes that there is
            reason to believe

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person has abused the adult, and

the adult is unable, for any of the reasons mentioned in section 44
                (c), to seek support and assistance.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The designated agency must involve the adult, to the greatest extent possible, in
          decisions about how to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seek support and assistance, and

provide the support and assistance necessary to prevent abuse or neglect in the
            future.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A designated agency that prepares a support and assistance plan for an adult
            must explain the plan and the proposed services to the adult.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Health
                Care (Consent) and Care Facility (Admission) Act

bcl:text.#text:
If health care services or admission to a care facility is proposed in the
            support and assistance plan, the designated agency must ensure that the  is complied
            with.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
When explaining the support and assistance plan to the adult, the designated
            agency

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
must communicate with the adult in a manner appropriate to the adult's skills
              and abilities, and

may allow the adult's spouse or any relatives or friends who accompany the
              adult or who offer their assistance, to help the adult to understand or demonstrate an
              understanding of the support and assistance plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the adult decides not to accept the services proposed in the support and
            assistance plan, they must not be provided except under section 56 (3).

If the adult decides not to accept the services proposed in the support and
            assistance plan and the adult appears to be incapable of making that decision, the
            designated agency may ask the Public Guardian and Trustee to arrange for an assessment
            of whether the adult is incapable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for support and assistance orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A designated agency that prepares a support and assistance plan may apply to the
            court for an order authorizing the provision of services to the adult if the report of
            the assessment under section 53 (5) is that the adult is incapable of
            deciding not to accept the services proposed in the plan.

At least 7 days before the date set for hearing the application, the designated
            agency must serve a copy of the application on the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult who is the subject of the application;

the adult's spouse or, if the adult has no spouse, a near relative of the
              adult;

the person in charge of any hospital, facility or residence where the adult
              may be residing or receiving care;
the Public Guardian and Trustee;
[Not in force. Repealed 2006-33-2.]
the adult's attorney, representative or guardian;
[Repealed 2001-2-5.]
any person against whom an order is sought under section 56 (3);
any other person that the court may direct.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The application must be accompanied by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a support and assistance plan that is prepared by the designated agency and
              includes a statement of the adult's wishes if known, and
a report of the assessment under section 53 (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subsection (3) (b) does not apply if the only order being sought is an order
            under section 56 (3) (c).

Any of the following are entitled to be heard at the hearing of the application
            for the provision of services to the adult:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult;
any person served under section 54 (2);

any person supporting and assisting the adult who is the subject of the
              application;
any person from the designated agency;
any other person whom the court agrees to hear.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
It is up to the designated agency to prove on the balance of probabilities, that
            the adult who is the subject of the application needs and would benefit from the
            services proposed in the support and assistance plan.

On hearing the application for the provision of services to the adult, the court
            must consider whether or not the adult

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is abused or neglected,

is unable to seek support and assistance because of an illness, disease,
              injury or other condition that affects his or her ability to make decisions about the
              abuse or neglect, and

needs and would benefit from the services proposed in the support and
              assistance plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
When considering the things referred to in subsection (1), the court must take
            into account the information in the documents mentioned in section 54 (3).

If the court is satisfied about the matters set out in subsection
              (1), the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
make an order for the provision of support and assistance to the adult without
              his or her consent,

bcl:text.#text: make an order under Part 7 of the  for the support of the adult,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order a person the court finds has abused the adult

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
to stop residing at and stay away from the premises where the adult lives,
                unless the person is the owner or lessee of the premises,

not to visit, communicate with, harass or interfere with the
                adult,

not to have any contact or association with the adult or the adult's
                financial affairs, or
to comply with any other restriction of relations with the adult,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
order a person the court finds has abused or neglected the adult to pay for,
              or contribute towards, the adult's maintenance or services to be provided for the
              adult, or

make any other order the court thinks is appropriate and in the best interests
              of the adult.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In an order under subsection (3) (a), the court must specify the kinds
            of support and assistance that are to be provided for the adult, including any of the
            following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
admission to an available care facility, hospital or other facility for a
              specified period of up to one year;
the provision of available health care;

the provision of available social, recreational, educational, vocational or
              other similar services;

supervised residence in a care home, the adult's home or some other person's
              home, for a specified period of up to one year;

the provision, for a specified period of up to one year, of available services
              to ensure that the adult's financial affairs are properly managed and protected,
              including any services that may be offered by the Public Guardian and
              Trustee.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In an order made under this section, the court must choose the most effective,
            but the least restrictive and intrusive, way of providing support and
            assistance.

If an order is made under this section, the designated agency must serve a copy
            of the order on the persons who were served with the application under section 54
              (2).

An order made under subsection (3) (a) terminates one year after it is
            made or on an earlier date specified by the court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Review of support and assistance orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A designated agency that obtained a support and assistance order under section 56 (3) (a) must review the need for the order if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the designated agency has reason to believe that any of the adult's needs or
              the adult's ability to make decisions about support and assistance has changed
              significantly since the order was made, or

the adult, or a spokesperson for the adult, requests a review and has a
              substantial reason for doing so.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the review under subsection (1) demonstrates that any of the adult's
            needs or the adult's ability to make decisions about support and assistance has changed
            significantly, the designated agency must apply to the court to have the order changed
            or cancelled.
A designated agency that obtains a support and assistance order under section 56 (3) (a) may do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review the need for the order before it terminates;
apply to the court for a renewal of the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application under subsection (2) or (3), the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
change or cancel the order if the court is satisfied that any of the adult's
              needs or the adult's ability to make decisions about support and assistance has
              changed significantly, or

renew the order for a further period of up to one year if the court is
              satisfied that the adult still needs the support and assistance provided under
                section 56
                (3) (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A support and assistance order under section 56 (3) (a) may be
            renewed only once.

A person against whom an order is made under section 56 (3) may apply to the
            court to change or cancel the order.

On application under subsection (1), the court may change or cancel the
            order or make any other order it considers to be in the best interests of the adult who
            has been found to be abused or neglected.

A person from a designated agency may do anything referred to in subsection
              (2) without the adult's agreement if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult is apparently abused or neglected,

it is necessary, in the opinion of the person from the designated agency, to
              act without delay in order to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: preserve the adult's life,
prevent serious physical or mental harm to the adult, or
protect the adult's property from significant damage or loss, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adult is apparently incapable of giving or refusing consent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In the circumstances described in subsection (1), the designated
            agency may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
remove the adult from the premises and convey him or her to a safe
              place;
provide the adult with emergency health care;

inform the Public Guardian and Trustee that the adult's financial affairs need
              immediate protection;

take any other emergency measure that is necessary to protect the adult from
              harm.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
After providing the adult with the assistance and services mentioned in
            subsection (2), the designated agency may conduct investigations under sections 48
            and 49.

A party may appeal to the Supreme Court from an order made by the Provincial
            Court under this Part.

The time limit for bringing an appeal under subsection (1) is 40 days,
            beginning on the day after the order is made by the Provincial Court.
An appeal is brought by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a notice of appeal in a registry of the Supreme Court, and

serving a copy of the notice of appeal on the parties to the proceeding in
              which the order of the Provincial Court was made, unless a judge of the Supreme Court
              orders otherwise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Supreme Court Civil Rules apply to an appeal under subsection
              (1) to the extent that they are consistent with this section.

An appeal does not operate as a stay or suspend the operation of the order under
            appeal, unless a judge of the Supreme Court orders otherwise.

After hearing the appeal, the Supreme Court may do one or more of the
            following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm or rescind the order of the Provincial Court;
make any order that the Provincial Court could have made;
direct the Provincial Court to conduct a new hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On application, the Supreme Court may extend the time limit for bringing an
            appeal.

A person acting on behalf of or under the direction of a designated agency is
            not personally liable for anything done or omitted in good faith in the exercise or
            performance or the intended exercise or performance of a power, duty or function
            conferred under this Part on a designated agency.

Subsection
              (1) does not absolve a designated agency or the government from vicarious
            liability for an act or omission for which it would be vicariously liable if this
            section were not in force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transfer of property by incapable adult

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an adult transfers an interest in the adult's property while the adult is
            incapable, the transfer is voidable against the adult unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the interest was transferred for full and valuable consideration, and that

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In a proceeding in respect of a transfer described in subsection (1), the onus

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Designated agencies and organization of community
          agencies
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Public Guardian and Trustee may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
by regulation, designate as agencies for the purposes of any or all of the
            provisions of Part 3 any public body, organization or person and limit their functions
            as designated agencies by reference to any factor that the Public Guardian and Trustee
            considers advisable,

organize networks of public bodies, organizations or persons for the provision
            of support and assistance to abused or neglected adults,

establish an agency to assist in planning or developing a network of public
            bodies, organizations or persons and in training staff, and

research the most effective ways of providing community and other services to
            carry out the purposes of this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A designated agency, a qualified health care provider and the Public Guardian and Trustee have the right to all the information necessary to enable them to perform their duties, powers and functions under this Act.

Any person who has custody or control of information that a designated agency, a qualified health care provider or the Public Guardian and Trustee is entitled to under subsection (1) must disclose that information to the designated agency, qualified health care provider or Public Guardian and Trustee, as applicable.
This section overrides

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any claim of confidentiality or privilege, except a claim based on solicitor-client privilege, and

bcl:text.#text: any restriction in an enactment or the common law about the disclosure or confidentiality of information, except a restriction in section 51 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A designated agency may disclose information obtained under this Act for the purposes of exercising the powers or performing the duties or functions of the designated agency under this Act.
The Public Guardian and Trustee may disclose information obtained under this Act for the purposes of exercising the powers or performing the duties or functions of the Public Guardian and Trustee.

A qualified health care provider who performs an assessment of an adult's incapability under this Act may disclose information obtained under this Act for the purposes of providing a report of the assessment to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Public Guardian and Trustee,
a health authority designate, for the purposes of exercising the powers or performing the duties or functions of the health authority designate under this Act,
a designated agency, for the purposes of exercising the powers or performing the duties or functions of the designated agency under this Act, and
a person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: makes a request, in writing, to the qualified health care provider for the report, and
confirms in the request that the report is to be used only for the purpose of an application to the court for an order under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) overrides any restriction in an enactment or the common law about the disclosure or confidentiality of information.
Nothing in this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
limits the inherent jurisdiction of the court to act in a parens patriae
              capacity, or

deprives a person of the right to ask the court to exercise that
              jurisdiction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Not in force.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: For any matter for which an application may be made under Part 2 or 2.1, or section 62.2 (2), the court may order that the costs of the application be paid from the property of the adult who is the subject of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
            make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing bodies for the purpose of the definition of "health authority designate" in section 1, and conferring on those bodies the authority to designate a person for the purpose of issuing a certificate of incapability under section 32;

bcl:text.#text: permitting a regional health board prescribed under paragraph (a) to authorize, by bylaw approved by the minister responsible for the , an employee to make the designation referred to in paragraph (a) on behalf of the regional health board;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purpose of the definition of "health care provider" in section 1, prescribing Acts for the purposes of Part 2.1 and for the purposes of Part 3;

prescribing classes of health care providers whose members may act as qualified health care providers, and conferring a discretion on bodies that regulate health care providers to put limits or conditions on those whom they regulate respecting eligibility to act as qualified health care providers;
respecting procedures for assessments of incapability, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing different procedures for assessments made for different purposes,
prescribing procedures if an assessment or part of an assessment is carried out by more than one qualified health care provider,
prescribing factors to be considered in an assessment of incapability, and
prescribing indicators of capability or incapability;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting requests by a qualified health care provider to other qualified persons for the purposes of seeking advice respecting an assessment;

bcl:text.#text: providing for exemptions from reassessments of incapability in relation to adults who are being discharged from a facility designated under the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the making of an assessment report and the contents of the report;
prescribing forms and certificates for the purposes of this Act;

prescribing offences for the purposes of sections 27 and 37;
respecting the service and content of a notice, and the opportunity to respond, for the purposes of section 32 (3.1), including respecting deemed receipt of a notice;
prescribing time limits within which a person must apply for a second assessment of incapability under section 33 (3);
[Not in force.]
respecting disclosure of information by the Public Guardian and Trustee under section 62.1;
defining words and expressions used but not defined in this Act.
